unnormalised: What yoga practices have significantly improved your life, and how?
normalised: What yoga practices have significantly improved your life, and how?

unnormalised: As someone who grew up in Rishikesh, the "Yoga Capital of the World," yoga wasn't just an exercise, it was woven into the very fabric of life. My life took a noticeable shift around 2015, when I started practicing consistently.
normalised: As someone who grew up in Rishikesh, the "Yoga Capital of the World," yoga wasn't just an exercise, it was woven into the very fabric of life. My life took a noticeable shift around two thousand and fifteen, when I started practicing consistently.

unnormalised: Initially, it was just Surya Namaskar every morning at 06:00 hrs, followed by some basic asanas. But as I delved deeper, inspired by teachers at the Parmarth Niketan Ashram, I incorporated Pranayama – especially Anulom Vilom. I found it incredibly helpful for managing stress, something I desperately needed while preparing for my MBA entrance exam.
normalised: Initially, it was just Surya Namaskar every morning at six hundred hours, followed by some basic asanas. But as I delved deeper, inspired by teachers at the Parmarth Niketan Ashram, I incorporated Pranayama – especially Anulom Vilom. I found it incredibly helpful for managing stress, something I desperately needed while preparing for my M B A entrance exam.

unnormalised: Later, while studying at IIM Ahmedabad, I discovered the calming effects of Yoga Nidra. Those 20-minute sessions felt like a reset button, especially during exam crunch times.
normalised: Later, while studying at I I M Ahmedabad, I discovered the calming effects of Yoga Nidra. Those twenty-minute sessions felt like a reset button, especially during exam crunch times.

unnormalised: What truly transformed me, though, was incorporating mindfulness into my practice, even during simple activities like drinking chai. It wasn’t about complex poses, but about being present. This has improved my focus, reduced anxiety, and overall, brought a sense of balance that I never thought possible. Even now, living in Bangalore and juggling a demanding job, I try to dedicate at least 30 minutes every day, after my 09:00 AM team meeting, to my practice. It's my anchor in the chaos.
